subject: Re: Test genes, test infected rates, and test-resistant managers
msgSnippet: ... Keeping in mind you re preaching to the choir... ;-) TDD may have a place in every organization, but IMHO in some the amount of work required to implement
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "albsavoia" <albsavoia@...> wrote:
>
>
> I am still surprised that, as we near the 10th, anniversary of JUnit
> (later this year) developer/unit testing, despite its obvious benefits
> and the fact that "it's the right thing to do", is still only practiced
> by a minority of developers in a minority of organizations. And, by
> practiced I mean, SERIOUSLY practiced. I talk with a lot of groups who
> say they *do* unit testing but have just a handful of test, rarely run,
> and no consistency, idea of code coverage, etc.

Keeping in mind you're preaching to the choir... ;-)

TDD may have a place in every organization, but IMHO in some the
amount of work required to implement it is monumental and perhaps even
prohibitive. If your codebase is dozens of 1000 line files of
function-less spaghetti code maintained by mulitple programmers across
multiple teams in various geographical locations... You (and your
organization) have a lot of work ahead of you before you can push TDD.

With that in mind, /starting/ effective code testing becomes the
hardest part, especially if nobody on your team--or even entire
company--has experience with unit testing. Further, if your codebase
isn't one that lends itself to testing, the programmers that developed
it probably need coding guidance before their code will be able to be
effectively tested.

Following another thread of thought...

TDD relies on "Type 1" people, as you called them (those that actively
champion TDD). Mentors. Champions. Zealots. It's amazing (and
sometimes scary, depending on context...) how receptive people are to
guidance from those that simply demand to be listened to.

If you're in an environment where TDD is not used/respected, do it
anyway, but not in a vacuum. Talk about it and mentor others in
understanding how to effectively write tests and /testable code/.
Further, demand that those around you do as well. Bring it up in
meetings. Admit your "failures"--when your code fails your own unit
tests. Count the number of times this happens. When bugs come up in
apps, "remind" the programmer fixing it to "be sure to write a unit
test for this so it doesn't happen again."

If you're interested in the big picture, identify those programmers
you think are most likely to leave your work environment and make sure
they understand and follow unit testing practices, knowing they'll be
the champion of unit testing (if not TDD) at the next place they go to.

Gabriel.
